<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 133, 636, 158]]<|/det|> # Cambridge International AS & A Level <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 183, 193, 213]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NAME <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 233, 175, 263]]<|/det|> CENTRE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 222, 425, 270]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[620, 233, 720, 263]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[735, 222, 905, 270]]<|/det|> <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 288, 178, 304]]<|/det|> ## PHYSICS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 288, 905, 304]]<|/det|> 9702/33 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 312, 359, 328]]<|/det|> Paper 3 Advanced Practical Skills 1 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 312, 905, 328]]<|/det|> May/June 2024 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[839, 337, 905, 352]]<|/det|> 2 hours <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 367, 395, 383]]<|/det|> You must answer on the question paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 395, 700, 412]]<|/det|> You will need: The materials and apparatus listed in the confidential instructions <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 431, 222, 446]]<|/det|> ## INSTRUCTIONS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 447, 892, 617]]<|/det|> INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You will be allowed to work with the apparatus for a maximum of 1 hour for each question.- You should record all your observations in the spaces provided in the question paper as soon as these observations are made.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units. <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 645, 213, 661]]<|/det|> ## INFORMATION <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 662, 728, 695]]<|/det|> INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ]. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[680, 743, 905, 870]]<|/det|>
For Examiner's Use

2
Total
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[269, 878, 727, 895]]<|/det|> This document has 12 pages. Any blank pages are indicated.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 81, 737, 101]]<|/det|>
You may not need to use all of the materials provided.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 114, 94, 131]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 114, 623, 131]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate a balanced metre rule.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 144, 623, 163]]<|/det|>
You have been provided with a metre rule and some masses.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 176, 144, 195]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 176, 611, 195]]<|/det|>
Place the masses on the rule as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 203, 868, 375]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 392, 532, 411]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 425, 180, 443]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 425, 559, 443]]<|/det|>
Place the \(100\mathrm{g}\) mass at one end of the rule.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 456, 175, 475]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 456, 915, 473]]<|/det|>
The distance between the centre of the \(100\mathrm{g}\) mass and the \(50\mathrm{cm}\) mark on the rule is \(a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 486, 384, 504]]<|/det|>
Measure and record \(a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 516, 917, 535]]<|/det|>
<form>a = ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 549, 175, 567]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 549, 866, 567]]<|/det|>
Place a \(10\mathrm{g}\) mass so that its centre is distance \(a\) from the \(50\mathrm{cm}\) mark on the rule.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 581, 173, 599]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 581, 920, 615]]<|/det|>
Secure this mass in place using the adhesive putty. **This mass must remain in place throughout the experiment.**

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 628, 175, 645]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 628, 888, 645]]<|/det|>
Place seven \(10\mathrm{g}\) masses so that their centres are above the \(50\mathrm{cm}\) mark on the rule.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[895, 642, 920, 660]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 82, 148, 101]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 82, 185, 101]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 82, 920, 117]]<|/det|>
Transfer \(n\) of the \(10\mathrm{g}\) masses, where \(n = 4\), from the centre of the rule onto the \(10\mathrm{g}\) mass near the end of the rule.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 129, 185, 148]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 129, 767, 149]]<|/det|>
Carefully place the rule and masses on the pivot as shown in Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[104, 156, 890, 311]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 320, 534, 339]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 352, 180, 369]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 352, 747, 371]]<|/det|>
Adjust the position of the rule on the pivot until the rule is balanced.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 383, 180, 401]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 383, 752, 401]]<|/det|>
The distance between the pivot and the \(50 \text{cm}\) mark on the rule is \(y\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 413, 329, 432]]<|/det|>
Record \(n\) and \(y\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 444, 917, 463]]<|/det|>
<form>n = ................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 475, 917, 494]]<|/det|>
<form>y = ................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 507, 180, 526]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 507, 667, 526]]<|/det|>
Remove the rule from the pivot and place it on the bench.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 537, 180, 556]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 537, 562, 556]]<|/det|>
Return the \(n\) 10g masses to the 50cm mark.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 553, 920, 571]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 81, 146, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 81, 920, 117]]<|/det|>
Change \(n\) by moving some of the \(10 \text{g}\) masses from the centre of the rule onto the \(10 \text{g}\) mass near the end of the rule and determine \(y\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 128, 576, 147]]<|/det|>
Repeat until you have six sets of values of \(n\) and \(y\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 160, 405, 179]]<|/det|>
Record your results in a table.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 183, 594, 211]]<|/det|>
Include values of \(\frac{1}{n}\) and \(\frac{y}{n}\) to three significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 516, 920, 535]]<|/det|>
<mark>[9]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 562, 144, 581]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 562, 175, 581]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 555, 648, 583]]<|/det|>
Plot a graph of \(\frac{y}{n}\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(\frac{1}{n}\) on the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 562, 920, 581]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 593, 180, 612]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 593, 457, 612]]<|/det|>
Draw the straight line of best fit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 593, 920, 612]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 625, 180, 643]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 624, 608, 643]]<|/det|>
Determine the gradient and \(y\)-intercept of this line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[495, 826, 920, 845]]<|/det|>
<form>gradient = ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 857, 920, 875]]<|/det|>
<form>y-intercept = ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 873, 920, 892]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[66, 114, 87, 133]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 114, 697, 133]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the properties of a rubber band.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 145, 141, 164]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 144, 180, 163]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 144, 584, 163]]<|/det|>
Set up the apparatus as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[292, 170, 700, 467]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 477, 532, 496]]<|/det|>
<mark>[b]Fig. 2.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 524, 220, 543]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 524, 672, 543]]<|/det|>
The rubber band should be straight but not stretched.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 555, 871, 574]]<|/det|>
The distance between the ends of the rubber band is \(L_0\), as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 586, 430, 605]]<|/det|>
Measure and record \(L_0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 617, 920, 636]]<|/det|>
<form>\(L_0 = ....................................................\) [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 648, 181, 667]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 648, 821, 667]]<|/det|>
Estimate the percentage uncertainty in your value of \(L_0\). Show your working.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[374, 803, 920, 822]]<|/det|>
<form>percentage uncertainty = ................................................. % [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 82, 143, 101]]<|/det|>
<label>(f)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 82, 751, 101]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that the percentage uncertainty in the values of \(k\) is \(25\%\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 112, 826, 131]]<|/det|>
Using this uncertainty, explain whether your results support the relationship in **(e)**.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 375, 186, 395]]<|/det|>
<label>(g)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 375, 670, 395]]<|/det|>
The approximate force \(F\) acting on the rubber band is given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[435, 410, 562, 448]]<|/det|>
\[F = \frac{2E\mathrm{tw}_0\Delta\mathrm{w}}{L_0}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 453, 623, 472]]<|/det|>
where the Young modulus \(E\) of rubber is \(1.0 \times 10^{6} \text{N} \text{m}^{-2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 484, 853, 503]]<|/det|>
Use your second value of \(k\) and your value of \(\Delta w\) from **(d)** to determine a value for \(F\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 715, 920, 734]]<|/det|>
<form>F = .................................................... N

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[918, 718, 923, 735]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 82, 146, 101]]<|/det|>
<label>(h)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 82, 185, 101]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>
